title: Equipotential map - electron moves from A to B

content.description: The figure shows an isoline map of electric potential in a region of space where there is an electric field. An electron is initially in motion at Point <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> and follows the path indicated by the dashed line as it travels through Point <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math>. Which of the following forms of energy will increase as the electron moves from Point <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> to Point <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math>, and what evidence or reasoning supports the claim?
content.question: <math alttext="U sub e f" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>U</mi><mtext>e-f</mtext></msub></math>, the electric potential energy of the electron-field system <math alttext="K sub e" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mtext>e</mtext></msub></math>, the kinetic energy of the electron

choices.label: <math alttext="U sub e f" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>U</mi><mtext>e-f</mtext></msub></math> increases. The electron moves from a lower to a higher electric potential.
<math alttext="U sub e f" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>U</mi><mtext>e-f</mtext></msub></math> increases. The electric field does positive work on the electron.
<math alttext="K sub e" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mtext>e</mtext></msub></math> increases. The electric potential magnitude is a minimum wherever it is zero.
<math alttext="K sub e" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mtext>e</mtext></msub></math> increases. The electron moves against a component of the electric field.

content.answer: <math alttext="K sub e" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mtext>e</mtext></msub></math> increases. The electron moves against a component of the electric field.

skill.text: 3.C: Justify or support a claim using evidence from experimental data, physical representations, or physical principles or laws.
